subject: English E1
description: Additional idioms from teacher's reference material

questions.question: What does the idiom 'a blessing in disguise' mean?
questions.answer: A good thing that seemed bad at first.
questions.example: Losing that job was a blessing in disguise - I found a much better one!

questions.question: What does the idiom 'a dime a dozen' mean?
questions.answer: Something very common and not special.
questions.example: Those kinds of toys are a dime a dozen at the market.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'beat around the bush' mean?
questions.answer: Avoid saying what you mean, usually because it is uncomfortable.
questions.example: Stop beating around the bush and tell me what happened.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'better late than never' mean?
questions.answer: It is better to arrive late than not to come at all.
questions.example: You finally submitted your project! Well, better late than never.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'bite the bullet' mean?
questions.answer: To get something over with because it is inevitable; to endure a painful situation.
questions.example: I hate going to the dentist, but I'll just have to bite the bullet.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'break a leg' mean?
questions.answer: Good luck (often said to performers before a show).
questions.example: You're performing tonight? Break a leg!

questions.question: What does the idiom 'call it a day' mean?
questions.answer: To stop working on something; to end the day's work.
questions.example: We've been working for hours. Let's call it a day.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'cut somebody some slack' mean?
questions.answer: Don't be so critical; give someone a break.
questions.example: He's new here, so cut him some slack.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'cutting corners' mean?
questions.answer: Doing something poorly or cheaply in order to save time or money.
questions.example: The builders were cutting corners, so the house has many problems now.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'easy does it' mean?
questions.answer: Slow down; be careful.
questions.example: Easy does it - that box is fragile!

questions.question: What does the idiom 'get out of hand' mean?
questions.answer: Get out of control.
questions.example: The party got out of hand and the neighbors complained.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'get your act together' mean?
questions.answer: Start behaving better or more responsibly.
questions.example: You need to get your act together and start studying seriously.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'give someone the benefit of the doubt' mean?
questions.answer: Trust what someone says without proof.
questions.example: I'll give him the benefit of the doubt and believe his excuse.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'go back to the drawing board' mean?
questions.answer: Start over; begin again from the beginning.
questions.example: That plan didn't work. Let's go back to the drawing board.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'hang in there' mean?
questions.answer: Don't give up; keep trying.
questions.example: I know it's tough, but hang in there - things will get better.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'hit the sack' mean?
questions.answer: Go to bed; go to sleep.
questions.example: I'm exhausted. I'm going to hit the sack early tonight.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'it's not rocket science' mean?
questions.answer: It's not complicated; it's easy to understand.
questions.example: Just follow the instructions - it's not rocket science.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'let someone off the hook' mean?
questions.answer: To not hold someone responsible for something.
questions.example: The teacher let him off the hook because it was his first offense.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'make a long story short' mean?
questions.answer: Tell something briefly; get to the point.
questions.example: To make a long story short, we missed the train and had to walk.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'miss the boat' mean?
questions.answer: It's too late; you've missed the opportunity.
questions.example: If you don't apply now, you'll miss the boat.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'no pain, no gain' mean?
questions.answer: You have to work hard for what you want.
questions.example: Keep exercising! No pain, no gain.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'on the ball' mean?
questions.answer: Doing a good job; being alert and competent.
questions.example: She's really on the ball - she noticed the error right away.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'pull someone's leg' mean?
questions.answer: To joke with someone; to tease playfully.
questions.example: I was just pulling your leg - I didn't really eat your chocolate.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'pull yourself together' mean?
questions.answer: Calm down; regain your composure.
questions.example: Pull yourself together - the interview is in five minutes.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'so far so good' mean?
questions.answer: Things are going well so far.
questions.example: How's the project going? So far so good!

questions.question: What does the idiom 'speak of the devil' mean?
questions.answer: The person we were just talking about showed up!
questions.example: We were just discussing Ram, and speak of the devil, here he comes!

questions.question: What does the idiom 'that's the last straw' mean?
questions.answer: My patience has run out; this is too much.
questions.example: You're late again? That's the last straw!

questions.question: What does the idiom 'the best of both worlds' mean?
questions.answer: An ideal situation where you enjoy two different advantages.
questions.example: Working from home gives me the best of both worlds - career and family time.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'time flies when you're having fun' mean?
questions.answer: You don't notice how long something lasts when it's enjoyable.
questions.example: Is it already 6 PM? Time flies when you're having fun!

questions.question: What does the idiom 'to get bent out of shape' mean?
questions.answer: To get upset or angry.
questions.example: Don't get bent out of shape - it was just a small mistake.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'to make matters worse' mean?
questions.answer: To make a bad situation even worse.
questions.example: I was already late, and to make matters worse, my car broke down.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'under the weather' mean?
questions.answer: Feeling sick or ill.
questions.example: I'm feeling a bit under the weather today, so I'll stay home.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'we'll cross that bridge when we come to it' mean?
questions.answer: We'll deal with that problem when it actually happens.
questions.example: What if we fail? We'll cross that bridge when we come to it.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'wrap your head around something' mean?
questions.answer: Understand something complicated.
questions.example: I can't wrap my head around this math problem.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'you can say that again' mean?
questions.answer: That's true; I completely agree.
questions.example: 'This weather is terrible!' 'You can say that again!'

questions.question: What does the idiom 'your guess is as good as mine' mean?
questions.answer: I have no idea; I don't know either.
questions.example: Where did he go? Your guess is as good as mine.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'a penny for your thoughts' mean?
questions.answer: Tell me what you're thinking.
questions.example: You look worried. A penny for your thoughts?

questions.question: What does the idiom 'a perfect storm' mean?
questions.answer: The worst possible situation; a combination of bad factors.
questions.example: Traffic, rain, and a flat tire - it was a perfect storm of problems.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'add insult to injury' mean?
questions.answer: To make a bad situation worse by doing something hurtful.
questions.example: He broke my phone and, to add insult to injury, blamed me for it.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'by the skin of your teeth' mean?
questions.answer: Just barely; very narrowly.
questions.example: I passed the exam by the skin of my teeth - just one mark above passing!

questions.question: What does the idiom 'comparing apples to oranges' mean?
questions.answer: Comparing two things that cannot be fairly compared.
questions.example: Comparing a car to a bicycle is like comparing apples to oranges.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'costs an arm and a leg' mean?
questions.answer: Very expensive.
questions.example: That designer bag costs an arm and a leg.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'at the drop of a hat' mean?
questions.answer: Do something immediately without planning.
questions.example: She can recite poems at the drop of a hat.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'don't cry over spilt milk' mean?
questions.answer: Don't complain about something that can't be fixed.
questions.example: The vase is broken. Don't cry over spilt milk - let's clean it up.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'give someone the cold shoulder' mean?
questions.answer: Ignore someone deliberately.
questions.example: Ever since our argument, she's been giving me the cold shoulder.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'go on a wild goose chase' mean?
questions.answer: To do something pointless; search for something impossible to find.
questions.example: Looking for that old document was a wild goose chase.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'he's a chip off the old block' mean?
questions.answer: The son is similar to his father in character or appearance.
questions.example: He loves cricket just like his dad - a real chip off the old block.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'hit the nail on the head' mean?
questions.answer: Get something exactly right.
questions.example: You hit the nail on the head with that analysis.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'ignorance is bliss' mean?
questions.answer: You're happier not knowing certain things.
questions.example: I didn't know about the problem until yesterday. Ignorance is bliss!

questions.question: What does the idiom 'it ain't over till the fat lady sings' mean?
questions.answer: This isn't finished yet; don't give up hope.
questions.example: We're losing, but it ain't over till the fat lady sings!

questions.question: What does the idiom 'it takes one to know one' mean?
questions.answer: You're just as bad as I am; you have the same fault.
questions.example: 'You're lazy!' 'It takes one to know one!'

questions.question: What does the idiom 'it's a piece of cake' mean?
questions.answer: It's very easy.
questions.example: Don't worry about the test - it's a piece of cake.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'it's raining cats and dogs' mean?
questions.answer: It's raining very heavily.
questions.example: Take an umbrella - it's raining cats and dogs outside.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'kill two birds with one stone' mean?
questions.answer: Accomplish two things with a single action.
questions.example: By cycling to work, I kill two birds with one stone - exercise and commuting.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'once in a blue moon' mean?
questions.answer: Very rarely.
questions.example: I only eat pizza once in a blue moon.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'play devil's advocate' mean?
questions.answer: To argue the opposite side just for the sake of argument.
questions.example: Let me play devil's advocate - what if the plan fails?

questions.question: What does the idiom 'put something on ice' mean?
questions.answer: Put a project on hold; postpone something.
questions.example: Let's put this project on ice until next month.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'rain on someone's parade' mean?
questions.answer: To spoil someone's plans or happiness.
questions.example: I don't want to rain on your parade, but there might be a problem.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'saving for a rainy day' mean?
questions.answer: Saving money for future needs or emergencies.
questions.example: I always save some money for a rainy day.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'spill the beans' mean?
questions.answer: Reveal a secret.
questions.example: Don't spill the beans about the surprise party!

questions.question: What does the idiom 'take a rain check' mean?
questions.answer: Postpone an offer to another time.
questions.example: I can't come today, but can I take a rain check for next week?

questions.question: What does the idiom 'take it with a grain of salt' mean?
questions.answer: Don't take it too seriously; be skeptical.
questions.example: He exaggerates, so take his stories with a grain of salt.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'the ball is in your court' mean?
questions.answer: It's your decision; it's your turn to act.
questions.example: I've made my offer. The ball is in your court now.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'the best thing since sliced bread' mean?
questions.answer: A really good invention or idea.
questions.example: This new app is the best thing since sliced bread!

questions.question: What does the idiom 'the devil is in the details' mean?
questions.answer: Small things can cause big problems; details matter.
questions.example: The plan looks good, but the devil is in the details.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'the elephant in the room' mean?
questions.answer: An obvious problem that everyone is ignoring.
questions.example: Let's address the elephant in the room - we're over budget.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'the whole nine yards' mean?
questions.answer: Everything; all of it.
questions.example: She wanted the party with decorations, cake, music - the whole nine yards.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'there are other fish in the sea' mean?
questions.answer: There are other opportunities available.
questions.example: Don't be sad about that job - there are other fish in the sea.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'there's a method to his madness' mean?
questions.answer: His strange behavior actually has a purpose.
questions.example: His approach seems odd, but there's a method to his madness.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'throw caution to the wind' mean?
questions.answer: Take a risk; act recklessly.
questions.example: She threw caution to the wind and quit her job to travel.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'on thin ice' mean?
questions.answer: In a risky situation; likely to get in trouble.
questions.example: After missing two deadlines, he's on thin ice with his boss.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'burn bridges' mean?
questions.answer: Destroy relationships or opportunities permanently.
questions.example: Don't burn bridges when you leave a job - you might need references.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'calm before the storm' mean?
questions.answer: A peaceful period before trouble arrives.
questions.example: Everything seemed fine, but it was just the calm before the storm.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'come rain or shine' mean?
questions.answer: No matter what happens; in any circumstances.
questions.example: I'll be there, come rain or shine.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'curiosity killed the cat' mean?
questions.answer: Being too curious can lead to trouble.
questions.example: Stop asking so many questions - curiosity killed the cat!

questions.question: What does the idiom 'cut the mustard' mean?
questions.answer: Meet the required standard; do a good enough job.
questions.example: His work just doesn't cut the mustard anymore.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'don't beat a dead horse' mean?
questions.answer: Stop wasting time on something that's already over.
questions.example: That topic is finished - don't beat a dead horse.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'every dog has his day' mean?
questions.answer: Everyone gets a chance to succeed at some point.
questions.example: I'll win someday - every dog has his day.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'fit as a fiddle' mean?
questions.answer: In very good health.
questions.example: After his recovery, he's as fit as a fiddle.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'get a second wind' mean?
questions.answer: Get renewed energy after being tired.
questions.example: After a short break, I got my second wind and finished the work.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'go down in flames' mean?
questions.answer: Fail spectacularly.
questions.example: His business idea went down in flames.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'have your head in the clouds' mean?
questions.answer: Not paying attention; daydreaming.
questions.example: She has her head in the clouds during class.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'he who laughs last laughs loudest' mean?
questions.answer: The final winner will have the greatest satisfaction.
questions.example: They laughed at my idea, but he who laughs last laughs loudest.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'hear something straight from the horse's mouth' mean?
questions.answer: Hear information directly from the source.
questions.example: I heard it straight from the horse's mouth - the boss told me himself.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'he's not playing with a full deck' mean?
questions.answer: He's not very smart; he's a bit crazy.
questions.example: His ideas are strange - I don't think he's playing with a full deck.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'he's sitting on the fence' mean?
questions.answer: He can't make up his mind; he's undecided.
questions.example: Stop sitting on the fence and make a decision!

questions.question: What does the idiom 'jump on the bandwagon' mean?
questions.answer: Follow a popular trend; do what everyone else is doing.
questions.example: Everyone's jumping on the bandwagon with this new diet.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'leave no stone unturned' mean?
questions.answer: Search everywhere; try every possibility.
questions.example: The police left no stone unturned in their investigation.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'let sleeping dogs lie' mean?
questions.answer: Don't disturb a situation that might cause trouble.
questions.example: Don't mention that old argument - let sleeping dogs lie.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'like riding a bicycle' mean?
questions.answer: Something you never forget how to do.
questions.example: Don't worry, playing piano is like riding a bicycle - it'll come back to you.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'like two peas in a pod' mean?
questions.answer: Very similar; always together.
questions.example: Those twins are like two peas in a pod.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'once bitten, twice shy' mean?
questions.answer: If you've been hurt before, you're more careful next time.
questions.example: After losing money in stocks, I'm cautious now - once bitten, twice shy.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'out of the frying pan and into the fire' mean?
questions.answer: Going from a bad situation to an even worse one.
questions.example: Quitting that job for this one was out of the frying pan and into the fire.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'run like the wind' mean?
questions.answer: Run very fast.
questions.example: When he heard the bell, he ran like the wind to class.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'shape up or ship out' mean?
questions.answer: Improve your behavior or leave.
questions.example: The coach told him: shape up or ship out!

questions.question: What does the idiom 'snowed under' mean?
questions.answer: Overwhelmed with work.
questions.example: I'm snowed under with assignments this week.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'that ship has sailed' mean?
questions.answer: It's too late; the opportunity has passed.
questions.example: I wanted to apologize but that ship has sailed - she's moved away.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'the pot calling the kettle black' mean?
questions.answer: Criticizing someone for a fault you have yourself.
questions.example: You're calling me lazy? That's the pot calling the kettle black!

questions.question: What does the idiom 'through thick and thin' mean?
questions.answer: Through good times and bad times.
questions.example: True friends stay together through thick and thin.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'when it rains it pours' mean?
questions.answer: Problems tend to come all at once.
questions.example: First my phone broke, then my car - when it rains it pours!
